Hi Maximo;

You have posed a difficult problem with no clear answer.  
This=
 however is quite normal when dealing with Japanese swords, there never see=
ms to be a simple answer.

There were a number of Mihara smiths who were na=
med Masaie and signed Masaie.

The Mihara were divided onto two groups base=
d on their work styles and the period they worked,

In the Ko Mihara of the=
 Kamakura period, circa 1300, the founder of the Mihara school was named Ma=
saie.

The work style of the Ko Mihara was koshi sori, with high and wide s=
hinogi, and iori mune. 
They made mostly tachi and tanto with a few shoto. =

The hada I have seen are a tight ko-itame and the color of the ji is fairl=
y dark
and there is ji nie and there is utsuri present.  The hamon is mostl=
y a narrow suguha, the nioi is wide and deep. and there is ashi and sometim=
es yo.  
The boshi is ko maru or o maru on a small kissaki.  The nakago is =
ha agiri kurijiri.  
The mei is usually cut in the center of the nakago, cu=
t with a fine chisel but the kanji are large and deep cut.

The Sue Mihara =
worked in the Muromachi period from the end of the Nambokucho period. 
They=
 made mostly katana, wakizashi and tanto.  
The quality of their work was n=
ot of the standard of the earlier generations and was inferior. 
They made =
mostly shinogi zukiri blades and the style and shape of the blades was simi=
lar to the Ko Mihara, but not as elegant or well proportioned.  
They tempe=
red in a suguha as did the earlier smiths but it is wider and also a gunome=
 midare.  
Quite often there is usually utsuri present and blades with very=
 little or no activity in the ha are the most common.  
The mei is cut smal=
ler and not as deep as the earlier generations. and are cut closer to the m=
une, and the mei are longer.

In general the older blades are more elegant =
and better proportioned and the ji is much darker.

I hope this helps a lit=
tle.

John
